units.title: Organoid Derivation from Tissue
units.text: Patient resection material is cut into small pieces, washed thoroughly and digested with collagenase. After additional washing and filtration, the digested tissue is plated in basement membrane extract (BME) and supplemented with expansion medium (Fig. 2b,c).
units.rationale: This is a clear, actionable step in the protocol for initiating organoid culture from tissue samples.

units.title: Organoid Maintenance and Passaging
units.text: Organoids can be passaged 7–21 d after organoid establishment (Steps 1–40) or after the previous split at a 1:2–1:8 ratio. Refer to Table 1 for a guideline. The time of passage and split ratio should be optimized for each newly established organoid culture based on confluency.
units.rationale: This provides specific, measurable criteria for maintaining organoid cultures over time.

units.title: Organoid Dissociation Methods
units.text: We describe both single-cell organoid passaging by trypsinization (Step 43A; Fig. 2g) and passaging via organoid fragments by mechanical disruption, referred to as shearing (Step 43B; Fig. 2g).
units.rationale: This details two distinct procedural methods for organoid passaging, essential for protocol replication.

units.title: Genetic Manipulation via Lipofectamine 2000
units.text: Lipofectamine 2000 for transient transfection with moderate-to-high efficiency (Step 65A), electroporation for transient transfection with high efficiency (Step 65B; used for Fig. S4 of ref. 7) or lentiviral transduction (Step 65C).
units.rationale: This lists specific, named methods with step references for genetic modification of organoids.

units.title: Clonal Organoid Selection
units.text: Using single cells, as opposed to fragments, will increase the likelihood that the organoids growing out after selection (e.g., by puromycin) indeed originate from single cells and are, thus, clonal.
units.rationale: This provides a critical procedural rationale for achieving clonality during selection after genetic manipulation.

units.title: Xenotransplantation via Orthotopic Injection
units.text: Finally, we introduce an optimized method for orthotopic organoid transplantation in mice, which includes injection of organoids and estrogen pellets without the need for surgery.
units.rationale: This describes a key in vivo procedure with a specific, non-surgical method for tumor formation.

units.title: Preparation of Type 1 and Type 2 Expansion Media
units.text: We describe the preparation of an expansion medium that was previously published7 (referred to as ‘Type 1’; Table 2). In addition, we introduce an alternative expansion medium, similar to that developed for long-term ovarian cancer organoid cultures18 (referred to as ‘Type 2’; Table 2), which can improve the growth properties of some organoid cultures (Fig. 2a and Table 1).
units.rationale: This instructs the preparation of two defined culture media with specific components and purposes.

units.title: Tissue Digestion Protocol
units.text: Add 500 µl of collagenase (20 mg/ml stock, final concentration 1 mg/ml) and 10 µl of ROCK inhibitor (10 mM stock, final concentration 10 µM) to the 50-ml Falcon tube containing the minced tissue. Wrap the 50-ml Falcon tube with Paraﬁlm and place the tube at a slight angle (~15°) on top of an orbital shaker located inside a heated incubator oven at 37 °C. Set the orbital shaker at 140 r.p.m. and digest the tissue for 1–2 h.
units.rationale: This is a precise, step-by-step procedure for enzymatic tissue digestion with exact reagents, conditions, and timing.

units.title: BME Plating for Organoid Culture
units.text: Plate 100 µl of BME-containing cells in multiple small drops (<20 µl each) per well in a 12-well plate (Fig. 2e). Turn the plate upside down and leave in the biosafety cabinet for 5 min. Transfer the plate, upside down, into a 37 °C incubator and leave to solidify for 30 min.
units.rationale: This provides exact, actionable steps for preparing 3D organoid cultures using BME, including orientation and timing.

units.title: Cryopreservation of Organoids
units.text: We recommend cryopreserving at least six cryovials for each newly established organoid culture at an early passage (< passage 5).
units.rationale: This gives a clear, quantitative guideline for preserving organoid lines to ensure long-term availability.
